title: Teaching Math at the Grocery Store – They Won't Even Know They're Learning
description: No workbooks, no desk, no fights. Math is everywhere if you know where to look.
imageAlt: Parent and child shopping together doing math

content.intro: "Mom, how much is this?" – "$3.50. I'm giving you $10, what's the change?" That's how I "teach" math at Target. My daughter doesn't know she's learning.

sections.text: Where Math Hides in Daily Life

items: "We need 6 apples. There are 4 in the bag. How many more?"
"Which is cheaper per ounce?" (comparison)
"We have $20 for snacks. Can we afford all this?"
"Count the items in our cart."
"The recipe needs 2 cups. We're doubling it – how much?"
"Cut the pizza into 8 slices. How many per person for 4 people?"
"Set the timer for 15 minutes. What time will it ring?"
"We need 3/4 cup. This is 1/4 cup – how many scoops?"
"We're going 60 miles. At 30 mph, how long will it take?"
"Count red cars vs. blue cars – who wins?"
"The speed limit is 45. Are we going faster or slower?"
"License plate math: add those numbers together."
"Help me measure this room for the new rug."
"Sort these coins and tell me the total."
"What time should we leave if we need to be there at 3:00 and it takes 20 minutes?"
"How many days until your birthday?"

sections.text: The key: Ask questions casually. No "this is a math problem" energy. Just conversation.

items: No pressure – it's just chatting
Context makes abstract numbers meaningful
Shows math is useful, not just school stuff
Multiple short exposures > one long session
Builds confidence without tests

rows: Turn it into a test with pressure
Make every moment a teaching moment
Adding, subtracting, skip counting, basic time

faq.question: What if they don't want to answer?
faq.answer: Don't force it! Just answer yourself out loud: "Hmm, I think the change would be $6.50." Model thinking, don't demand it.

faq.question: Is this enough for their math development?
faq.answer: No – this supplements formal learning, not replaces it. But it builds number sense that makes formal math easier.

faq.question: My child catches on that I'm "teaching" – then refuses.
faq.answer: Be more subtle. Instead of direct questions, think aloud: "I wonder how much change we'll get..." Sometimes they'll chime in, sometimes they won't.
